questions.question: A smoker presents with an oral lesion, as shown in the image below. Which stain is used to identify this pathology?
questions.explanation: blue is used for identification, and it is a supravital stain. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not used to identify laryngeal mass. Reference: .

questions.question: Which among the following is the least radiosensitive cell?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Platelets Explanation: Among the given options, platelets are the least radiosensitive cells. Radiosensitivity refers to the susceptibility of cells or tissues to the effects of radiation. Cells with higher rates of proliferation and less differentiation tend to be more radiosensitive because they are actively dividing and thus more vulnerable to the damaging effects of radiation. Platelets are the least radiosensitive as they do not divide actively. Order of Radiosensitivity: Lymphocytes > neutrophils ~ monocytes > platelets Reference: Radiation sensitivity of human and murine peripheral blood lymphocytes, stem and progenitor cells - ScienceDirect .

questions.question: Which of the following instruments is not used in the colorimetric method for the estimation of hemoglobin? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: colorimetric method for the estimation of hemoglobin, it is designed for manual blood cell counting. Incorrect Options: The images in Options A, B, and C show a comparator, hemoglobin tube, and a stirrer respectively. They are components of Sahli's hemoglobinometer set. Sahli's method of hemoglobin estimation is a colorimetric method. Parts of Sahliâ€™s hemoglobinometer set: Comparator Hemoglobin Tube Hemoglobin Pipette Stirrer Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the criteria for diagnosis of Kawasaki disease?
questions.explanation: non-purulent conjunctivitis rather than purulent conjunctivitis. Incorrect Options: Options A, B & D: Strawberry tongue, Polymorphic rash, and Cervical lymphadenopathy are all features of Kawasaki disease. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following disorders presents with repeated catalase-positive infections?
questions.explanation: by a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex. Without a functional NADPH oxidase, the patient is susceptible to recurrent infections caused by catalase-positive organisms. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are not associated with recurrent catalase-positive infections. Reference: .

questions.question: A Diabetic patient's blood sample is kept in the given container. What will be added to the blood sample?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Na fluoride Explanation: Grey top containers, used for glucose estimation, contain potassium oxalate as an anticoagulant and sodium fluoride to inhibit glycolysis by blocking enolase. Colour Anti-coagulants Uses Purple/Lavender EDTA (Ca2+ chelating anticoagulant) (Option B ruled out) CBC, Peripheral Smear, ESR, HbA1c Light Blue Trisodium Citrate (Ca2+ chelating anticoagulant) (Option C ruled out) ESR, PT, aPTT Red No anti-coagulant is added. Clot activator without gel Serum studies (Proteins, enzymes, hormones) Yellow Clot activator/Gel separator Serum studies (Proteins, enzymes, hormones) Grey Sodium Fluoride (Option A) Blood Glucose Green Heparin (Option D ruled out) ABG, Osmotic fragility, flow cytometry, immunophenotyping

questions.question: Which amino acid is necessary for the production of nitric oxide in the blood vessels?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Arginine Explanation: Nitric oxide (NO) is a vital signalling molecule involved in vasodilation and various other physiological processes. Nitric oxide synthesis in blood vessels requires the amino acid arginine , which serves as its precursor. Steps in Nitric Oxide Synthesis: Enzyme Involved : Nitric oxide synthase (NOS) converts L-arginine to nitric oxide (NO) and L-citrulline in the presence of oxygen and cofactors like NADPH and tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4). Physiological Role of NO : NO is a potent vasodilator that relaxes vascular smooth muscle cells, thus regulating blood pressure and improving blood flow. It also has roles in neurotransmission and immune response. Citrulline (Option A) is a byproduct of nitric oxide synthesis and can be recycled back into arginine via the urea cycle , but it is not directly used in NO production. Histidine (Option C) is a precursor for histamine and is involved in immune responses, but it does not play a role in NO synthesis. Tryptophan (Option D) is a precursor for serotonin and melatonin but is not involved in nitric oxide production. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34251644/
